Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: High-performance phase modulators and tunable birefringent filters based on negative index superlattices
Award.AbstractNarration:
The research team is developing a photonic crystal platform technology based on negative refraction superlattices designed to implement high-performance phase modulators and tunable birefringent filters for use in optical communication modules. This technology is with chip-scale photonic crystal elements, highly wavelength-dispersive and potentially low-loss structures allows for high-density integration into modules. Since the devices are based on negative refraction photonic crystal superlattices which have strong wavelengths and phase sensitivity, they have low-voltage/power requirements for modulation.

Current optoelectric modules are large and require high power and high voltages. This technology provides a small, low power, low voltage module. The smaller size, would enable devices to be integrated into large numbers on silicon chips and enhance communications technologies.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual merit: The I-Corps innovation grant provides a unique training opportunity in commercializing technology from scientific research. In developing the business approach, the entrepreneur lead (a postdoc scientist in our team), the entrepreneur mentor, and the principal investigator interviewed more than 100 customers and companies, learning of their key needs. This bottom-up approach, rather than a top-down technology first approach, gives us clear insight on the technology steps and market space. This innovation training program also allowed us to build the team camaraderie and the contacts towards possible commercialization and startups. Lessons and tutorials in the entrepreneurship process were also helpful.

The entrepreneur postdoc learnt to present his scientific advancements to a general and non-scientific audience. He learnt how to encapsulate the technology for market leaders, in an elevator pitch. This industry or commercial perspective is synergistic with the scientific development, highlighting which components in the optical communication and data server chains are the most important. This also gave an outside-the-lab perspective on the technology scaling and performance requirements for successful startups. This innovation grant gave us the chance to discuss with current silicon photonics startups, as well as the people in the market movers category on the insights and next steps.

Broader impact: This non-conventional grant gave us an opportunity to tap into and map from our core scientific advancements into entrepreneurship ventures. It brings a refreshing perspective on the pace and core contributions of science and engineering to our society.
